source.1ed63266:
# Boxplot of categorical variables

plt.figure(figsize=(30, 30))
sns.set(style="darkgrid")
i=1
for col in cat_var:
    plt.subplot(12,4,i)
    sns.countplot(data=train, x=col)
    i=i+1
plt.show()
source.00d9285f:
plt.figure(figsize=(20 , 20))
corr = train.corr()
mask = np.zeros_like(corr, dtype=np.bool)
mask[np.triu_indices_from(mask)] = True
sns.heatmap(corr, square=True, mask = mask, cmap='coolwarm_r', annot_kws={'size':20})
source.f36cee10:
m = (corr.mask(np.eye(len(corr), dtype=bool)).abs() > 0.5).any()
raw = corr.loc[m, m]
raw
source.4f251a39:
#histogram of numeric values.
num_col= [col for col in train_pd.columns if (col not in cat_var) ]
num_col1=num_col[:49]
plt.figure(figsize=(100, 100))
i=1
for col in num_col1:
    plt.subplot(10,5,i)
    sns.histplot(data=train, x=col)
    plt.title(col+" distribution")
    i=i+1
plt.show()
source.d0207a30:
## EDA Observations:

1) dataset consisits of 287 columns

2) train data dimesntions are (1000000, 287)

3) test data dimensions are(500000, 286)

4) target variable iss categorical and there are equal numbers ofinstance in both class (0 and 1)

5) Out of 286 coulmns 49 are categorical variable and rest are numeric variable.

6) There is no null values in dataset. 

7) almost all variable follow the normal distribution and some of them are right skewed.

8)  There is only one variable that has more than 0.5 correlation, rest all have <0.5.
